request_pathways.name: Authorization to Use or Disclose PHI (Brown University Health)
HIM Department mail (593 Eddy Street, Providence, RI 02903)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form, fills it by hand, and submits via fax or mail to the HIM department.

red_flags: Broad liability waiver bundled with records authorization form
No electronic delivery option offered (paper or CD only in a 2024 form)
Vague fee language without amounts or patient-access fee distinction
bright_spots: Granular record-type selection with ~10 categories plus behavioral health subsection
Sensitive information exclusions respecting 42 CFR Part 2 and Rhode Island state law
Multi-facility coverage with clear selection checkboxes on a single form
Easy online findability with dedicated medical records request page

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with a simple web search; first query immediately surfaced the form, and a dedicated medical records page exists at a logical URL path — but not prominently linked from the homepage.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Born-digital PDF with text layer is usable with annotation workarounds, and fax submission is available, but the form has zero fillable fields requiring a print-and-handwrite workflow.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate 11-section numbered structure with logical flow, but dense legal language, no plain-language summary or instructions, and cramped single-page layout create notable clarity issues.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form by checking 'Patient Request' as the purpose, but the form is designed for third-party release — requiring the patient to fill in themselves as the recipient with no acknowledgment of individual access rights.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Broad liability waiver bundled into authorization goes beyond legal requirements; vague fee language may not distinguish HIPAA-capped patient-access fees; no Right of Access reference — though revocation rights and right to refuse are properly stated.

overall.summary: Rhode Island Hospital provides an easily findable but generic authorization form that lacks fillable fields, a patient-access-specific pathway, and electronic delivery options, placing it in the average tier despite good organization and sensitive-information protections.
